Graphical abstract The study focused on investigating the role of CuPt bimetallic active sites in CO oxidation. First, there is an electron transfer phenomenon from the Cu sites to the Pt sites, resulting in a significant change in the surface electron distribution of Cu. This leads to the suppression of strong CO adsorption on Cu while simultaneously creating sites for O2 adsorption. Following this, CO interacts with CuPt NPs on the catalyst surface to form Cu–CO and Pt–CO and then reacts with adsorbed oxygen to produce CO2. Catalytic oxidation processes for carbon monoxide (CO) typically rely on catalysts made from noble metals. However, due to the scarcity and high cost of noble metals, developing low–cost, highly active, and stable catalysts with low noble metal loading is highly demanded but challenging. Herein, we synthesized ZrO2–supported CuPt alloy nanoparticle (NP) catalyst (0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2), with a Cu loading of 0.3 wt% and a Pt loading of 0.1 wt%, using a straightforward impregnation method. This catalyst structure enables the well-mixing of Cu and Pt atoms in the pristine and partially oxidized catalysts during the CO oxidation. The temperature for 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2 to reach 90 % CO conversion is 160 °C, which is much lower than those for 0.1Pt/ZrO2 (220 °C) and 0.4Cu/ZrO2 (195 °C). Extensive characterizations were conducted, particularly for the pristine catalysts. The experiments and density functional theory (DFT) calculations results reveal that the interaction between the two metals significantly modified the electronic property of the catalyst. On CuPt bimetallic sites, the electron transfer from Cu to Pt weakens the strong adsorption of CO, and Cu species provide sites for O2 adsorption, which synergistically promotes the CO oxidation on the surface of CuPt NPs. This research provides deep insights into the relationship between the catalyst structure and their catalytic performance and paves the way for developing highly active bimetallic synergistic catalysts for CO oxidation. Keywords CuPt bimetallic catalysts CO oxidation Competitive adsorption Catalytic performance Interfacial structure Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction CO is a major atmospheric pollutant primarily emitted from the incomplete combustion of carbon–based fuels. It is commonly found in vehicle exhaust and industrial emissions [1–3]. Catalytic oxidation is an effective method for CO purification [4]. Noble metals, like Pt [5], Pd [6], Ag [7], and Au [8], are commonly used in CO oxidation catalysts. However, due to the limited reserves of noble metals and their high production and use costs, using these noble metals can be expensive [9–11]. Hence, discovering methods to decrease the usage of noble metals to reduce costs while still maintaining excellent catalytic performance, particularly at low temperatures (≤150 °C), continues to be a major challenge. Any advancement in this field will have substantial implications for scientific research and industrial applications. At present, supported Pt catalysts have attracted much attention due to their high CO oxidation activity and reaction stability [12–14]. However, the high price of Pt and its easy–poisoning properties by CO pose significant challenges to its continuous application [15–17]. In recent years, there have been numerous efforts to decrease the use of Pt while maintaining high catalytic performance. Using a rational structural design for bimetallic catalysts allows for reduced platinum usage and enables the adjustment of activity compared to single platinum catalysts [18,19]. It has been reported that modifying Pt–CeO2 with transition metal oxides (M = Fe, Co, and Ni) could enhance the redox properties of the support, reducing the adsorption strength of CO and preventing CO poisoning [20]. Additionally, introducing the inexpensive metal Ni to form a Pt–Ni bimetallic catalyst in the appropriate Pt/Ni proportion could alleviate CO poisoning to Pt [21]. Therefore, substituting noble metals with affordable transition metals is a viable solution. Cu group metals have been widely studied because of their abundant resources, low cost, and high intrinsic catalytic activity [22–24]. The greater electronegativity of Pt than Cu can cause electron transfer, which is expected to modulate surface electronic properties that affect the catalytic performance [25,26]. The previous study by Gonçalves et al. [27] demonstrated that the presence of Cu active sites was functional for CO oxidation. However, the limited stability of Cu catalysts hinders their practical application [28–30]. It is suggested that combining the strong stability of the noble metal Pt with Cu may address this issue. The previous study found that PdCu and RhCu bimetallic NPs exhibited better CO oxidation activity than Pd and Rh NPs [31]. This is because the Cu formed very active and stable Pd–CuO NPs or Rh–CuO interfaces, which could significantly improve their catalytic activity. Kim et al. [32] synthesized an AuCu/SiO2 catalyst with an abundant Au–CuO x interface for CO oxidation reaction. Oxygen vacancies in the CuO x /Au interface were found to promote the effective conversion of CO through the Mars–Van Krevelen mechanism. Furthermore, Cu sites on Pt NPs could enhance the electro–oxidation of CO by providing a binding site with selective OH adsorption for CO oxidation [33]. However, while these studies showed that Cu can enhance the catalytic activity of noble metals, the specific role that Cu plays in CO oxidation, particularly in common Pt catalysts, remains to be clarified. Based on the previous efforts and our understanding, in this work, we prepared a ZrO2–supported well–mixed CuPt bimetallic catalyst (0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2) by direct impregnation technique. Control experiments show that 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2 exhibited a much higher CO oxidation activity than 0.1Pt/ZrO2 and 0.4Cu/ZrO2, and the physically mixed 0.1Pt/ZrO2 + 0.4Cu/ZrO2 catalyst. The characterization and theoretical calculation results suggest that the synergistic effect in CuPt bimetallic NPs boosts the catalytic activity of 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2. The enhanced electron transfer from Cu to Pt modifies the electronic properties of the catalyst surface, thereby promoting CO desorption. In situ DRIFTS and DFT simulation shows that Cu provides adsorption sites for O2 and promotes further CO oxidation on the surface. Hence, this study clarifies the synergistic effect of bimetal sites in CO oxidation and lays a foundation for designing efficient bimetallic catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals and materials Chloroplatinic acid hexahydrate (H2PtCl66H2O, analytical grade (AR), Pt ≥ 37.5 wt%) and copper nitrate hydrate (Cu(NO3)23H2O, AR, ≥ 99.9 wt%) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. Zirconium dioxide (ZrO2, AR, ≥ 99.9 wt%, specific surface area: 40 m2/g) was bought from Zhejiang Yamei Nano Technology Co. Ltd. All the chemicals were used directly without further purification. 2.2 Preparation of the catalysts 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2: 10 mg of H2PtCl66H2O (0.1 wt% nominal loading of Pt) and 23 mg of Cu(NO3)23H2O (0.3 wt% nominal loading of Cu) were dissolved in 9 mL of deionized water. Subsequently, 2.0 g of ZrO2 powder was added to the above–mixed solution and stirred at room temperature for 1 h. The resultant slurry was dried at 100 °C overnight, followed by calcination in air at 400 °C for 3 h, with a ramp rate of 5 °C /min. The calcined material was then reduced in a tubular furnace under a hydrogen flow (≥99.9 vol%, 60 mL/min) at 250 °C for 2 h, with the same ramp rate. After H2 reduction, the reduced sample was cooled to room temperature, denoted as 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2. 0.1Pt/ZrO2: 10 mg H2PtCl66H2O (0.1 wt% nominal loading of Pt) was dissolved in 9 mL deionized water. Subsequently, 2.0 g of ZrO2 powder was added into the above H2PtCl6 solution and stirred at room temperature for 1 h. The resulting slurry was dried at 100 °C overnight and then calcined at 400 °C for 3 h in air at a heating rate of 5 °C /min. The calcined material was then reduced in a tubular furnace under a hydrogen flow (≥99.9 vol%, 60 mL/min) at 250 °C for 2 h, with the same ramp rate. After H2 reduction, the reduced sample was cooled to room temperature, denoted as 0.1Pt/ZrO2. 0.4Cu/ZrO2: 30 mg of Cu(NO3)23H2O (0.4 wt% nominal loading of Cu) was dissolved in 9 mL deionized water. Subsequently, 2.0 g of ZrO2 powder was added to the above Cu(NO3)2 solution and stirred at room temperature for 1 h. The resulting slurry was dried at 100 °C overnight and then calcined at 400 °C for 3 h in air at a heating rate of 5 °C /min. The calcined material was then reduced in a tubular furnace under a hydrogen flow (≥99.9 vol%, 60 mL/min) at 250 °C for 2 h, with the same ramp rate. After H2 reduction, the reduced sample was cooled to room temperature, denoted as 0.4Cu/ZrO2. Pure ZrO2: The preparation conditions were the same as mentioned above but without the addition of Cu(NO3)23H2O and H2PtCl66H2O precursors. The resulting sample is referred to as Pure ZrO2. 0.1Pt/ZrO2 + 0.4Cu/ZrO2: It was obtained by physically mixing 0.1Pt/ZrO2 and 0.4Cu/ZrO2 with a mass ratio of 1:1, denoted as 0.1Pt/ZrO2 + 0.4Cu/ZrO2. 2.3 Characterization Transmission electron microscope (TEM) and scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) analyses were conducted using a JEOL JEM 2100F system equipped with a field emission gun at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. Before TEM experiments, all samples were reduced at 250 °C for 2 h in an atmosphere of H2, and then N2 was introduced to purge the catalyst surface. The samples are placed in a vacuum bag to avoid oxidation and ensure a dry state. X–ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were measured on a PANalytical X'Pert PRO MPD using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) at 40 kV and 200 mA, and compared with the standard XRD patterns provided by the Joint Committee on Powder Diffraction Standards (JCPDS). X–ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra were recorded using a Thermo Scientific K–Alpha spectrometer, which is equipped with monochromatized Al Kα radiation (1486.6 eV). The spectrometer was operated at 12 kV and 6 mA under pressure below 2.0 × 10–5 Pa to analyze the valence of each element. All binding energies were calibrated to the C 1 s peak at 284.8 eV of the adventitious carbon. Before XPS experiments, all samples were reduced at 250 °C for 2 h in an atmosphere of H2, and then N2 was introduced to purge the catalyst surface. The samples were placed in a vacuum bag to avoid oxidation and ensure a dry state. The used samples were obtained using the same protection treatment after CO oxidation. The metal content in the samples was measured by inductively coupled plasma−optical emission spectroscopy (ICP–MS, Agilent 7800, America). The hydrogen temperature–programmed reduction (H2–TPR) experiments were conducted on an automated chemisorption analyzer (Quantachrome, ChemBET Pulsar TPR). CO temperature–programmed desorption (CO–TPD) and O2 temperature–programmed desorption (O2–TPD) experiments were performed on a Micromeritics Autochem II 2920 and an Altamira instrument AMI–300 chemisorption analyzer, respectively. For H2–TPR, a 0.15 g sample was loaded in a quartz U–tube, heated from room temperature to 150 °C at 10 °C /min, and maintained for 2 h under a helium (He) flow. Then, the sample was cooled to 50 °C, followed by heating to 900 °C at 10 °C /min under a binary gas (10.0 vol% H2/Ar) with a gas flow of 100 mL/min. For CO–TPD, a 0.05 g sample was placed in a reaction tube and dried at 10 °C /min from room temperature to 120 °C. Then, the sample was cooled to room temperature and saturated with 10 % CO/He. After the physically adsorbed CO was removed by purging with He for 1 h, the sample was heated to 800 °C at 10 °C /min in a He flow (30 mL/min). A thermal conductivity detector (TCD) was used to detect the desorbed CO gas. For O2–TPD, a 0.1 g sample was placed in a reaction tube and dried at 10 °C /min from room temperature to 120 °C. Then, the sample was cooled to room temperature and saturated with 10 % O2/He. After the physically adsorbed O2 was removed by purging with He for 1 h, the sample was heated to 800 °C at 10 °C /min in a He flow (30 mL/min). TCD was used to detect the desorbed oxygen gas. In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (In situ DRIFTS) spectra were collected continuously using a TENSOR 27 spectrometer equipped with an MCT detector cooled by liquid nitrogen. The sample was placed on the sample holder at the center of the cell. The sample was placed in a reaction tube, dried from room temperature to 200 °C at 10 °C /min in an N2 atmosphere, and then cooled to 50 °C, followed by flowing CO (2 % CO/N2, 50 mL/min). The adsorption of CO molecules on the catalyst surface lasted for 30 min. After that, the DRIFTS spectra were recorded until there was no visible change in the absorption band intensity under the N2 purge. For the experiment in the CO–O2–N2 atmosphere, the sample was first dried from room temperature to 200 °C at a rate of 10 °C /min in an N2 atmosphere, then cooled to 50 °C and adsorbed in 2 % CO/N2 for 30 min, then the gas was switched to 5 % O2/N2 for 30 min, and finally swept with N2. All these spectra were collected by accumulating 32 scans in 600–4000 cm−1 range at a resolution of 4 cm−1 as a function of time. The CO pulse adsorption test was conducted using the BSD–Chem C200 instrument. A 0.15 g sample was reduced with H2 at 250 °C for 2 h, with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. After cooling the temperature down to 50 °C, excess H2 was removed using a high–purity He gas flow. Subsequently, the dispersion and particle size of the metal were measured using the CO pulse technique. 2.4 Catalytic measurement The CO oxidation reaction was performed using a continuous flow system in a stainless steel fixed–bed reactor under atmospheric pressure. The feed gas (1 vol% CO, 16 vol% O2, and 83 vol% N2 as balance gas) was purchased from Beijing Haipu Gas Co. Ltd. Firstly, 0.2 g of catalyst (20–40 mesh) was placed into the reactor. Subsequently, the feed gas was introduced into the reactor with a 200 mL/min flow rate and a weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 60, 000 mL−1·g−1·h−1. The reaction temperature was increased from 50 to 230 °C at a heating rate of 5 °C /min, where each point was maintained for 45 min to stabilize. The Testo 350 pro multi–component flue gas analyzer was used to measure the concentration of CO at the inlet and outlet. The CO conversion was calculated as follows: (1) X C O = V C O in - V C O out V C O in × 100 % where XCO is CO conversion, and V C O in and V C O out represent the CO concentration at the inlet and outlet, respectively. CO conversion was controlled below 20 % by varying the WHSV and reaction temperature to eliminate the effects of internal and external diffusion. Then, the specific reaction rate and turnover frequency (TOF) of CO oxidation were measured. The reaction rate (molCO·molmetal –1·s−1) is calculated as follows: (2) CO Reaction rate = X CO × F CO n × 100 % where XCO is CO conversion (< 20 %), FCO (mol/s) is the molar gas flow rate of CO, and n (molmetal) is the molar amount of the metal in the catalyst. The TOF on active metal sites (TOFmetal (s−1)) is calculated by the following equation: (3) TOF metal = X CO × F CO × M metal m × W metal × D metal × 100 % where XCO is CO conversion (< 20 %), FCO (mol/s) is the molar gas flow rate of CO, Mmatal is the atomic weight of the active metal, Wmetal is the active metal loading, and Dmetal is the dispersion of active metal. The apparent activation energies (Ea (kJ/mol)) over the catalysts were calculated via the Arrhenius equation at CO conversions below 20 %. 2.5 Computational methods and models All the periodic DFT calculations were performed through the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [34,35], using the Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) functional [36]. The core electrons were treated with the projector augmented–wave (PAW) pseudopotentials. The used plane wave cutoff energy was 450 eV. The Monkhorst–Pack grid was set as a gamma point. The convergence criterion for the geometric relaxation was 0.02 eV/Å. The adsorption energy was calculated through the following equations: Eads = Emol/sub – (Emol + Esub). The Emol/sub represents the energy of the whole adsorbed system, Emol is the energy of a free molecule, Esub is the energy of a substrate. Four layers of ZrO2 (111) and a Cu7Pt3 cluster were used to explore the adsorption behaviors and reaction mechanisms. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the catalyst 3.1.1 TEM observation Fig. 1 presents the TEM images of the 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2, 0.1Pt/ZrO2, and 0.4Cu/ZrO2 catalysts. The ZrO2 lattice can be seen for all the catalysts, with spacings of 0.311, 0.362, 0.499, and 0.181 nm attributed to the ZrO2 ( 1 ¯ 1 1 ) , (110), (100), and (022) crystal planes, respectively [37]. In 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2, the CuPt NPs with a diameter of ∼ 2 nm are loaded on ZrO2 support with sizes of 15–30 nm. High–resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images (Fig. 1a) show the lattice spacing of 0.218 nm, which corresponds to the (111) crystal plane of CuPt NPs (Fig. 1b) [38]. For 0.1Pt/ZrO2, Pt NPs possess an average size of 3.9 nm, and the lattice spacing of 0.225 nm is related to the Pt (111) crystal plane (Fig. 1c and d) [39]. The Cu NPs in 0.4Cu/ZrO2 possess an average size of 5.4 nm, and the lattice spacing of 0.208 nm corresponds to the Cu (111) crystal plane (Fig. 1e and f) [8]. The lattice spacing of CuPt NPs is 0.218 nm, which is between the lattice spacing of single metal Pt (0.225 nm) and Cu (0.208 nm), indicating the formation of the Cu–Pt alloy particles [40]. To further prove the existence of CuPt alloy in the bimetallic catalyst, the STEM dark field images of 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2 are measured, as shown in Fig. 2 . There are small metal nanoparticles loaded on the ZrO2 support (Fig. 2a, blue circle). EDS mapping (Fig. 2b) shows that the small metal particles are composed of Cu and Pt elements (Fig. 2c). The overlayered EDS images Fig. 2b and the elemental mapping of Cu, Pt, and Zr (Fig. 2d–g) reveal the uniform distribution of Cu and Pt on CuPt NPs. To confirm this, we further scanned the surface of the catalyst (Fig. 2h) and found that the elemental peaks of Cu and Pt are almost at the same position. These findings demonstrate the formation of the well–mixed or even alloyed CuPt bimetallic NPs, which enable the effective interaction between metal sites. Furthermore, the H2–TPR (Fig. 3 a) and CO–adsorption DRIFTS (Fig. 6) experiments confirmed such kind of interaction between the two metals. 3.1.2 H2–TPR, CO–TPD, O2–TPD, and XRD analysis Fig. 3a presents the H2–TPR profiles of all the catalysts after their calcination in air, which reflect the reducibility and metal–metal interaction of the catalysts. For 0.1Pt/ZrO2, the peak at 243 °C is attributed to the reduction of the PtO x species [41]. The peak at 268 °C for 0.4Cu/ZrO2 is attributed to the reduction of CuO x species [42]. The strong reduction peak at 256 °C in 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2 is attributed to the reduction of Pt–[O] x –Cu structure, which is different from the reduction peak of either PtO x (243 °C) or CuO x (268 °C) species. This indicates a strong interaction between the Pt and Cu species [5,43], which provides indirect evidence of forming CuPt alloy NPs. Furthermore, the individual temperature profile illustrates the uniform dispersion of bimetallic NPs. Fig. 3b shows the CO–TPD profiles of all the catalysts after their reduction in H2 gas. Before CO–TPD analysis, the weakly adsorbed CO on the catalyst surface was removed by He purging. Two types of CO desorption peaks can be observed. The low–temperature strong desorption peak around 142.1 °C is assigned to CO adsorbed on the metal sites, which plays the key role in CO oxidation. The high–temperature weak desorption peak at about 500.4 °C is not significantly different. The order of the low–temperature strong desorption peak area is 0.4Cu/ZrO2 > 0.1Pt/ZrO2 > 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2 (Fig. 3b). The strong adsorption of CO deactivates catalysts because CO molecules might cover the active sites [44]. Compared to 0.1Pt/ZrO2 and 0.4Cu/ZrO2, 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2 shows a lower CO desorption temperature and weaker CO adsorption, indicating less covered surface sites on it. To further investigate the oxygen adsorption and activation on 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2, 0.1Pt/ZrO2, and 0.4Cu/ZrO2 catalysts, O2–TPD experiments were conducted for these catalysts after their reduction in H2 (Fig. 3c). The desorption of surface adsorbed oxygen species follows a sequence with increasing temperature: from surface adsorbed peroxo species (O2 −, below 200 °C, OIII) to surface adsorbed monoatomic species (O−, 200 − 500 °C, OII), transitioning to surface lattice oxygen (O2−, 500 − 700 °C, OI), and finally to bulk lattice oxygen (above 700 °C) [44]. It should be pointed out that before the O2–TPD analysis, the physically adsorbed oxygen was removed through He purging. The peak above 500 °C is related to the surface lattice oxygen species, which are not directly involved in the reaction [45]. Table 1 shows the area of the oxygen desorption peaks for each catalyst. The oxygen desorption peak area follows 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2 > 0.4Cu/ZrO2 > 0.1Pt/ZrO2. No obvious OIII below 200 °C is observed for 0.4Cu/ZrO2, while 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2 show a prominent peak of OIII, and the peak area much larger than of 0.1Pt/ZrO2. This indicates that the formation of PtCu NPs increases the oxygen storage capacity for weak chemisorption. The OII peak area of 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2 is significantly larger than that of the other two catalysts. These results show that 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2 has the largest capacity for surface–adsorbed oxygen species due to the formation of CuPt NPs. Fig. 3d presents the XRD patterns of the catalysts. Characteristic diffraction peaks are only observed at 2θ values of 17.4, 24.4, 28.2, 31.4, 49.2, and 50.1°, corresponding to the monoclinic ZrO2 crystal planes of (100), (110), ( 1 ¯ 1 1 ) , (111), (022), and (220), respectively (JCPDS No. 86–1449). No other peaks are observed, confirming the high purity of the ZrO2 sample. Furthermore, crystalline phases of Pt and Cu species are not discernible due to their low concentration and/or high dispersion on the ZrO2 surface. 3.1.3 XPS analysis Fig. 4 a displays the Cu 2p spectra of 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2 and 0.4Cu/ZrO2. The samples were reduced in H2 before the XPS analysis. The peaks at 932.6 and 952.7 eV are attributed to the Cu0 species, and the peaks at 935.1 and 955.0 eV to the Cu2+ species [46]. Compared with 0.4Cu/ZrO2, the Cu0 peak of Cu 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 in 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2 shift to higher binding energies (BEs) by 0.2 and 0.5 eV, respectively, indicating the partial electron transfer from Cu to Pt. Fig. 4b shows the Pt 4f spectra of 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2 and 0.4Cu/ZrO2. The peaks at 70.1 and 74.1 eV are attributed to Pt0, and those at 72.7 and 75.6 eV are attributed to Pt2+. The peaks at 74.8 and 78.3 eV are attributed to Pt4+ [37,47]. Compared with 0.1Pt/ZrO2, the Pt0 peak of Pt 4f7/2 and 4f5/2 of 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2 shift to lower BEs by 0.5 and 0.2 eV, respectively. These observations indicate that the electronic properties of Pt are modified due to the gain of electrons from Cu [48]. For Zr 3d spectra (Fig. 4c), two peaks at 181.8 and 184.7 eV are the BEs of 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 electrons of Zr4+, respectively [49,50]. The Zr 3d signals of the three catalysts are observed with similar intensity. Also, the peak shape remains consistent, although there is a slight shift observed. This shift may be attributed to the higher electronegativity of copper (Cu, 1.9) and platinum (Pt, 2.2) compared to zirconium (Zr, 1.3), which affects the Zr 3d signals [51]. As a result, the Zr peaks of the three catalysts cannot be accurately assessed. Fig. 4d shows the O 1 s spectra of all the catalysts. Two distinct characteristic peaks are observed: the lattice oxygen (OI) at 529.8 eV in ZrO2 and the surface–adsorbed oxygen species (OII) at 532.5 eV. OII represents the molecular oxygen, and other oxygen species adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst [37]. Compared with other catalysts (70.5 % for 0.4Cu/ZrO2 and 62.7 % for 0.1Pt/ZrO2), the proportion of OII in 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2 (78.3 %) is the highest. 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2 surface has the largest amount of the adsorbed oxygen species, which coincides with the above O2–TPD test results (Fig. 3c). These observations indicate that forming CuPt alloy NPs improves the oxygen adsorption capacity of the catalyst. Compared with the O 1 s spectra of the fresh 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2, after CO oxidation, a new peak of O 1 s spectra appears at about 531.4 eV for 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2, which proves the existence of new chemisorbed oxygen species on the CuPt bimetallic NPs (Fig. 4e). Furthermore, the OII peak has almost completely disappeared, proving that the OII species are the reactive species for CO oxidation. For the Cu site, O2 pre–adsorption led to the appearance of Cu+ species (933.4 eV and 953.3 eV), with a concurrent disappearance of Cu0 (932.7 eV and 952.5 eV). Following the pre–adsorption of CO + O2, Cu0 species were restored (Fig. 4f) [52]. Similarly, for Pt sites, Pt2+ species emerged during O2 pre–adsorption, replacing Pt0. However, after the pre–adsorption of CO + O2, the Pt2+ (75.8 eV and 72.7 eV) sites were reduced back to Pt0 (74.1 eV and 70.1 eV) (Fig. 4g). This process illustrates the role of Cu in the catalyst, which stabilizes the metallic Pt as the active site for CO oxidation, while Cu species likely facilitate the adsorption of molecular O2 and its activation. 3.2 Catalytic performance of the catalysts The catalytic performance of the ZrO2–supported catalysts for CO oxidation was evaluated using a gas mixture (1.0 vol% CO/16 vol% O2/N2) at a WHSV of 60, 000 mL·g−1·h−1. As depicted in Fig. 5 a, pristine ZrO2 exhibits an ignorable CO oxidation performance. The order of the catalytic activity of the ZrO2–supported catalysts for CO oxidation is as follows: 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2 > 0.4Cu/ZrO2 > 0.1Pt/ZrO2. The CO conversion reaches 90 % on 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2 at only 160 °C, which is lower than the temperature of 0.1Pt/ZrO2 (220 °C) and 0.4Cu/ZrO2 (195 °C). The excellent performance of 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2 compared with other ZrO2–supported catalysts is due to the alloying effect of Pt and Cu in the pristine catalyst, and their intimate contact during the catalytic process. Conversely, the CO oxidation performance of the physically mixed 0.1Pt/ZrO2 + 0.4Cu/ZrO2 catalyst is lower than that of 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2, confirming that the separated Cu and Pt sites cannot function well synergistically for the CO oxidation. The long–term stability of a catalyst is a critical factor in its practical application. The durability of 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2 was evaluated in a prolonged stability test at 150 °C. Fig. 5b shows that the CO conversion is 64 % within 50 h at 150 °C without any visible deactivation, indicating that 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2 has excellent catalytic stability. The intrinsic reaction rates and apparent activation energies of CO oxidation were further measured to compare the activity of the catalysts. For 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2, the reaction rate is 8.6 × 10–4 molCO·molmetal –1·s−1 at 140 °C (Fig. 5c), which is higher than those of 0.1Pt/ZrO2 (1.0 × 10–4 molCO·molmetal –1·s−1) and 0.4Cu/ZrO2 (4.7 × 10–4 molCO·molmetal –1·s−1). Fig. 5d shows the activation energy (Ea) of all the catalysts. Compared with 0.1Pt/ZrO2 (41.3 kJ/mol) and 0.4Cu/ZrO2 (38.4 kJ/mol), 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2 has the lowest Ea value of 30.9 kJ/mol, further indicating its highest catalytic activity. Standard CO chemisorption was performed on 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2, 0.4Cu/ZrO2, and 0.1Pt/ZrO2 to measure active metal dispersion, metallic metal surface, and cubic crystallite size (Table 2 ). For the 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2 sample, the measured dispersion, surface area, and average particle size values of the active metal are between those of 0.4Cu/ZrO2 and 0.1Pt/ZrO2, indicating that there is a synergistic effect between Cu and Pt. Table 3 summarizes the TOFs of the Cu and Pt–based catalysts reported under similar reaction conditions. The TOFs of 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2 measured at 70 °C is 4.90 × 10−2 s−1, which is higher than that of 0.4Cu/ZrO2 (1.20 × 10−2 s−1) and 0.1Pt/ZrO2 (0.60 × 10−2 s−1), suggesting that the former exhibits a much stronger CO oxidation activity. It is worth noting that the TOF value of 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2 at 70 °C obtained in this work is even higher than that of the reported catalysts in Table 3 at higher reaction temperatures. To elucidate the CO oxidation mechanism on the two catalysts, we determined the reaction orders for CO and O2, as depicted in Fig. 5e and f. The CO reaction order on 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2 is –0.29, exceeding that of 0.4Cu/ZrO2 (–0.40), indicating that the former is more resistant to CO poisoning. The reaction order for O2 was 0.1 for 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2 and 0.2 for 0.4Cu/ZrO2. The lower O2 reaction order for 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2 suggests less competitive adsorption between CO and O2 and a lower energy barrier for O2 activation, which will be proven again by the following DFT calculations. 3.3 In situ DRIFTS analysis Fig. 6 a–c presents the DRIFTS spectra of CO adsorption on 0.1Pt/ZrO2, 0.4Cu/ZrO2, and 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2. Strong gas–phase CO absorption bands are observed on 0.1Pt/ZrO2 at 2112 and 2171 cm−1, accompanied by a CO bridge absorption band at 1822 cm−1 [61]. The bridge adsorption of CO was observed on 0.1Pt/ZrO2 but not on 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2, indicating the separation effect of Cu in the alloyed Cu-Pt NPs. The electron redistribution on the Cu and Pt atoms can facilitate linear adsorption [62,63]. Thus, the in Situ DRIFTS results confirm the well–mixed Cu and Pt elements at the atomic level in the alloyed nanoparticles. The observed peaks at 1639, 1537, 1460, and 1394 cm−1 on the three catalysts are attributed to the bidentate carbonate intermediate species [6,64]. 0.1Pt/ZrO2 exhibits a characteristic linear Pt–CO adsorption vibration at 2065 cm−1 [14], which shifts to 2060 cm−1 upon N2 purging (Fig. 6d). For 0.4Cu/ZrO2, two strong absorption bands are observed at 2109 and 2171 cm−1, which are attributed to Cuδ+–CO species and gaseous CO [24,65]. During the N2 purge process, the gaseous CO peak in the case of 0.4Cu/ZrO2 gradually decayed within the initial 10 mins and completely disappeared at 20 mins. The linear CO adsorption completely disappeared at 30 mins (Fig. 6e). For 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2, CO adsorption shows two different bands at 2170 and 2109 cm−1, which are attributed to linear CO adsorption and gas–phase CO adsorption, respectively. During the N2 purge process, the gaseous CO peak of the 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2 catalyst gradually decayed in about 10 min and completely disappeared at 20 min. However, the linear CO adsorption did not change significantly (Fig. 6f) [60]. A notable redshift is observed on 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2 compared to 0.1Pt/ZrO2 before N2 purging, suggesting a synergy effect due to the electron transfer from Cu to Pt. This surface composition aligns with the results from the H2–TPR analysis (Fig. 3a). The observed CO adsorption strength from the in situ DRIFTS spectra is consistent with the CO chemisorption data (Fig. 3b). This further suggests that excessive CO adsorption can reduce catalytic performance. To further explore the adsorption of CO and O2 on 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2, we measured the in situ DRIFTS spectra by switching among various gas atmospheres of “CO–O2–N2” at 50 and 160 °C (Fig. 7 ), respectively. At 50 °C, when introducing O2, the bands at 2108 and 2173 cm−1 became weak, and all disappeared at 8 min. The peaks of Cu0 − CO (2085 cm−1), Cuδ+ − CO (2108 cm−1), gas phase CO (2173 cm−1), and Pt0 − CO (2065 cm−1) were observed at 14 min, and there was no significant change within 30 min after adsorption, which confirms the reliability of the structural characterization of CuPt NPs (Fig. 7a and b) [66]. In addition, in the CO–O2–N2 switching process, the peak position of Pt0 − CO maintained at 2065 cm−1 and the absorption peak intensity became lower, while the Cu0 − CO peak shifted from 2085 cm−1 to 2082 cm−1 during N2 purging (Fig. 7c). It is thus evident that the Cu sites in CuPt NPs act as sites for O2 adsorption and decrease the intensity of CO adsorption on Pt to prevent poisoning [67]. To detect the role of CuPt NPs in CO oxidation, we performed the same in situ DRIFTS experiment at 160 °C. The adsorption peak intensity of CO on Cuδ+ − CO (2111 cm−1) and Pt0 − CO (2062 cm−1) became strong. After introducing O2, the Cuδ+ − CO peak disappeared, but the Cu0 − CO peak appeared (2084 cm−1). At the same time, the peak intensity of Cu0 − CO and Pt0 − CO became stronger, indicating that both Cu and Pt sites adsorbed CO at the high temperature of 160 °C (Fig. 7d and e). Compared with the results at 50 °C (Fig. 7c), the CO peak on the Cu and Pt sites had a smaller wavenumber shift (Fig. 7f), indicating that high temperatures can provide sufficient energy for the Cu sites to activate gas oxygen to participate in CO oxidation. 3.4 DFT calculation From an experimental aspect, the ZrO2 support primarily exposes the (111) crystal plane. Transmission characterization reveals that the Cu content in the CuPt bimetallic system significantly exceeds that of Pt. Previous studies on M10 cluster modeling have demonstrated that Pt10 exhibits exceptional stability and structural diversity [68–70]. Similarly, the bimetallic cluster Au7Cu3, modeled on this structure, also shares these advantages [71]. Consequently, we selected ZrO2 (111) and Cu7Pt3 as the model catalysts, positioning the Pt site within the cluster and the Cu site at the interface to establish a more accurate adsorption configuration (Fig. 8 ). The computational results indicate that the initial CO molecule can adsorb on either the Cu or Pt site (Fig. 8a and b). Characterization results further reveal that O2 and CO adsorption on metal sites play a critical role in CO oxidation, aligning closely with the Langmuir–Hinshelwood (LH) mechanism [72]. To better align the density functional theory (DFT) computational model with the catalyst structure under actual reaction conditions, we employed a model comprising a ZrO2 (111) surface and a Cu7Pt3 cluster, where the initial state was fully covered by CO and O2 molecules (Fig. 9 , IS). As shown in Fig. 9, the first elementary reaction involves the interaction between an O2 molecule and a CO molecule, overcoming an activation energy of 0.79 eV (TS1). In this step, O2 reacts with CO adsorbed on the Pt site to form an OCOO* intermediate (IM1), while Cu transitions into an oxidized state due to the adsorption and transformation of O2. Subsequently, CO2 is spontaneously formed and released, releasing 2.23 eV of energy (IM2). The cleavage of the O–O bond in the OCCO* intermediate results in the release of CO2, leaving behind an oxygen atom. At this stage, the oxidized Cu state is partially reduced, with an exothermic CO2 desorption energy of 1.31 eV (IM3). In the next step, a second CO molecule binds to the Pt site (IM4) and reacts with the remaining O* atom to form another CO2 molecule, requiring an activation energy of 1.46 eV (TS2). Finally, CO2 desorbs into the gas phase, returning the Pt and Cu sites to their initial states and completing the oxygen cycle (FS). Based on previous studies of catalytic cycling during CO oxidation, it was found that the leapfrogging behavior of O2 molecules at different sites drives the cycling of valence states [72,73]. This confirms the critical role of the O2 adsorption cycle, particularly at the Cu sites, in facilitating this mechanism. These findings are consistent with the results obtained from XPS and in situ DRIFTS analyses. 3.5 Proposed catalytic mechanism Based on the above characterizations, the structural model of the CuPt/ZrO2 catalyst is proposed to illustrate the reaction process, as shown in Fig. 10 . In general, CO is adsorbed on CuPt NPs and interacts with surface–adsorbed oxygen species to undergo an oxidation reaction at the Cu site to form CO2, which is a typical LH mechanism [74,75]. In the catalyst, some electrons are transferred from the Cu sites to the Pt sites, which significantly changes the surface electron distribution of Cu. As a result, the strong adsorption of CO on Cu is suppressed, which simultaneously provides sites for O2 adsorption. Subsequently, CO combines with CuPt NPs on the catalyst surface to form Cu–CO and Pt–CO, and further reacts with the adsorbed oxygen to form CO2. In the process, the synergetic interaction between Pt and Cu sites in CuPt NPs can reduce the competitive adsorption of CO and O2 at single metal sites and contribute to CO oxidation. 4 Conclusion ZrO2–supported CuPt alloy catalysts have been successfully synthesized by a simple impregnation method, which enables a mixing at the atomic level of Cu and Pt atoms even in their partially oxidized status during the CO oxidation. Compared to the individual Pt and Cu metal catalysts, the CuPt bimetallic catalyst shows higher activity and stability in the CO oxidation reaction. The characterization results, particularly to the pristine catalysts, show that both Pt and Cu can separately adsorb CO strongly, leading to the severe coverage of the active sites by CO. However, in the 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2 bimetallic catalyst, there is an electron transfer phenomenon from Cu to Pt atoms, which significantly alters the surface electronic properties and suppresses the excessive adsorption of CO on Pt. Also, this synergistic interaction leads to the enhanced ability for oxygen adsorption, thus greatly reducing the CO–poisoning effect and improving catalytic activity. In situ DRIFTS and DFT simulation results show that the LH mechanism is prominent, and the Cu site in CuPt NPs acts as the adsorption site for O2, which improves the competitive adsorption of CO and O2 on Pt and Cu metal sites. Therefore, this study offers a deep insight into the reaction mechanism of CO oxidation over CuPt bimetallic NPs, highlighting the significance of designing proper active centers for efficient and long–lasting catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic oxidation processes for carbon monoxide (CO) typically rely on catalysts made from noble metals. However, due to the scarcity and high cost of noble metals, developing low–cost, highly active, and stable catalysts with low noble metal loading is highly demanded but challenging. Herein, we synthesized ZrO2–supported CuPt alloy nanoparticle (NP) catalyst (0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2), with a Cu loading of 0.3 wt% and a Pt loading of 0.1 wt%, using a straightforward impregnation method. This catalyst structure enables the well-mixing of Cu and Pt atoms in the pristine and partially oxidized catalysts during the CO oxidation. The temperature for 0.3Cu0.1Pt/ZrO2 to reach 90 % CO conversion is 160 °C, which is much lower than those for 0.1Pt/ZrO2 (220 °C) and 0.4Cu/ZrO2 (195 °C). Extensive characterizations were conducted, particularly for the pristine catalysts. The experiments and density functional theory (DFT) calculations results reveal that the interaction between the two metals significantly modified the electronic property of the catalyst. On CuPt bimetallic sites, the electron transfer from Cu to Pt weakens the strong adsorption of CO, and Cu species provide sites for O2 adsorption, which synergistically promotes the CO oxidation on the surface of CuPt NPs. This research provides deep insights into the relationship between the catalyst structure and their catalytic performance and paves the way for developing highly active bimetallic synergistic catalysts for CO oxidation.
